Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) are regarded as a competitive next-generation energy storage device. However, their practical performance is seriously restricted due to the undesired polysulfides shuttling. Herein, a multifunctional interlayer composed of paper-derived carbon (PC) scaffold, Fe3O4 nanoparticles, graphene, and graphite sheets is designed for applications in LSBs. The porous PC skeleton formed by the interweaving long-fibers not only facilitates fast transfer of Li ions and electrons but also provides a physical barrier for the polysulfide shuttling. The secondary Fe3O4@graphene component can reduce the polarization, boost the attachment of polysulfides, and promote the charging-discharging kinetics. The outer graphitic sheets layers benefit the interfacial electrochemistry and the utilization of S-containing species. The efficient obstruction of polysulfides diffusion is further witnessed via in situ ultraviolet-visible characterization and first-principles simulations. When 73% sulfur/commercial acetylene black is used as the cathode, the cell exhibits excellent capacity retention with high capacities at 0.5 C for 1000 cycles and even up to 10 C for 500 cycles, an ultrahigh rate capability up to 10 C (478 mAh g−1), and a high areal-sulfur loading of 8.05 mg cm−2. The strategy paves the way for developing multifunctional composites for LSBs with superior performance. Graphical abstract Loading Fe3O4 nanoparticles on paper-derived carbon scaffold is demonstrated to greatly improve reversible capacity and cycle stability when used as the interlayer in lithium–sulfur batteries, because of the effective ionic sieve, which can selectively sieve Li+ ions while efficiently inhibiting undesired polysulfides from moving to the anode side. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Paper-derived carbon nanosheets Fe3O4 Lithium–sulfur batteries Multifunctional interlayer Polysulfides 1 Introduction Due to the ever-increasing energy demands and the severe environmental issues, developing renewable energy sources to replace the traditional fossil fuels is of high necessity and urgency [1,2]. In particular, the requirement of a high energy density has caused widespread concern in energy storage and the integration of smart grids [3]. Because of the limited theoretical specific capacity [4,5], traditional lithium–ion batteries based on lithium metal oxides (LiCoO2) or lithium phosphates (LiFePO4) cannot meet such stringent requirements. Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs), by contrast, have shown great promise due to the high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), high specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1), cost-effectiveness and environmental friendliness. Hence, LSBs are considered as a highly competitive candidate for applications in advanced portable electronics and hybrid-electric vehicles. Although LSBs had been proposed as early as in the 1960s [6], large-scale practical applications of LSBs are still hindered by several intrinsic obstacles, such as the poor electrical conductivity of sulfur and its discharge products (Li2S2/Li2S) [7,8], the shuttle effect of the soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) intermediates, and the serious volume variation during the discharge-charge processes. Furthermore, at least 10%–20% sulfur will be lost, either converted to LiPSs or dissolved into the electrolyte [9–11]. In order to address these issues, considerable strategies have been brought forward during the past few decades. Among them, one of the effective approaches is to impregnate sulfur into a matrix of conductive carbon material, like porous and hollow carbon [12–15], graphene [16,17], nanotubes [18,19], and nanofibers [20], to name a few. A highly integrated graphene-sulfur@polydopamine/high-strength binder composite has been developed as the cathode to aim at the long-lasting and high-sulfur-loading LSBs [17]. The above hosts, which possess distinct nanostructures and tailed morphologies, can effectively trap the LiPSs, remarkably beneficial to a long cycling life of the batteries [21]. Alternatively, implanting an interlayer between the sulfur cathode and the commercial separator can also effectively impede the migration of LiPSs, making the sulfur utilization promoted. In 2012, Manthiram et al. first introduced the microporous carbon paper as a functional interlayer in the Li-S system, wherein the capacity and the stability of the sulfur cathodes were significantly improved [22]. Subsequently, numerous carbon-based interlayers involving treated carbon paper [23], mesoporous carbon [24], carbonized eggshell membrane [25], carbonized cellulose paper [26,27], and carbon fiber cloth [28], have been extensively investigated. The aforementioned interlayers can act not only as a second current collector but also as a physical barrier to confine the electrochemical active species on the cathode side, due to the existence of the channels or pores with suitable sizes for the penetration of the electrolyte. However, the production of such structures are always at the expense of polysulfides across the interlayer. Hence, the interlayers should also be endowed with suitable polarity for the chemical confinement of LiPSs. In general, an excellent interlayer should integrate the merits of porosity, polarity and conductivity. Graphene, the carbon material with a unique two-dimensional (2D) structure, exhibits attractive features of an exceptional electronic conductivity (106 S m−1) [29] and a large surface area (~2630 m2 g−1) [30]. This makes the graphene-based assemblies beneficial to fast kinetics of the sulfur-involved reactions. Moreover, the hybridization of the carbon materials with metal nitrides [31,32], metal carbides [33], or metal single atoms [34–36] provides an alternative way to suppress the shuttling of LiPSs by strengthening the adsorption of polar Li2Sn. Meanwhile, the metal oxides/chalcogenides [37–39], such as MnO [40], TiO [41], Fe2O3 [42], and NiS [43] have been also proved to offer abundant adsorption sites to seize LiPSs. Thus, one can expect that the combination of graphene and metal oxides not only can maximize the advantages of the two constituents but also help inhibit the shuttle effect and improve the cycling stability. Unfortunately, the preparation of such materials often suffers from tedious procedures, high cost, and the difficulty to scale up the synthesis. Moreover, the performance of the sulfur cathodes at high rates is still barely satisfactory. To the end, developing a simple, reliable, and low-cost route is essential for the fabrication of high-quality interlayers that are composed of graphene and metal oxides for the improvement of the rate capability and the cycling stability. In this work, we have devised an easy-operation method to develop a novel and high-performance interlayer based on filter paper. Relying on the facile capillary adsorption, accessible immersion, drawing with a pencil, and calcination, the paper-derived carbon (PC) scaffold is successfully integrated with Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs), rGO sheets and graphite outface (PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite). The loading level and the size of Fe3O4 NPs can be controlled by changing the number of the capillary adsorption-immersion process cycle. Clearly, the present synthetic method is environmentally benign since water is the only solvent, in sharp contrast to previously reported approaches. The combined merits of the simple operation, low costs of the raw materials, and the eco-friendliness make our method be attractive for large-scale synthesis. Moreover, the unique architectures and the specific compositions of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite hybrid interlayer bring about multi-functionalities of the material, like the outstanding conductivity, enhanced polarity, good catalytic properties, and excellent mechanical ability. Notably, the hybrid interlayer can effectively inhibit the diffusion of the LiPSs, and, accordingly, makes the sulfur electrodes without complicated synthesis or surface modification manifest high reversible capacity, exceptional rate capability, and long cycling stability with even high sulfur loadings. The suppression of the shuttle effect comes from the strong interactions between the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite hybrid interlayer and the discharge LiPSs, as demonstrated by in situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) characterizations and first-principles calculations. The present work will inspire rational creations of multifunctional interlayers for the practical applications in energy-storage devices. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer In a typical synthesis, graphene oxide (GO) and ironic citrate solution with certain concentration were prepared firstly. Specifically, graphene oxide was synthesized from graphite powder (Aladdin, 325 mesh, 99.95%) by a modified Hummers methods [44]. GO aqueous suspension (2 mg/mL) was sonicated for 2 h at room temperature. 0.185 g ironic citrate heptahydrate was dissolved into 20 mL ultrapure water and then centrifuged to get clear supernatant. The filter paper (diameter of 7 cm, Xinxing) was pretreated. Typically, a piece of filter paper (diameter of 7 cm, Xinxing) was flat immersed into 1 mL GO solution and then dried at 60°C. The above procedure was repeated for three times. The edge of pretreated filter paper was immersed in the pre-fabricated ironic citrate solution to absorb for 20 min, sequentially processed by drying naturally to allow the ions to diffuse thoroughly. Then, the above paper was flat immersed in 1 mL GO solution. The combined adsorption of ironic citrate and immersion of GO was called one process cycle. After repeating three process cycles, the filter paper was drawn on both surface sides with a pencil to have thin layer of graphite. Finally, it was annealed at 800°C for 2 h in argon atmosphere and cut into discs with a diameter of 14 mm. 2.2 Preparation of PC interlayer To better illustrate the performance of our modified-interlayer, the PC interlayer was also prepared for the control sample. The filter paper was directly carbonized under 800°C for 2 h in argon atmosphere. 2.3 Materials characterization Field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) images were collected on Gemini500 (Zeiss). Images of transmission electron microscope (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), elemental mappings and HAADF-STEM were recorded on probe aberration-corrected JEOL ARM-200F field-emission transmission electron microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The crystal phase of samples were tested by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker-D8 Advance, Cu Kα radiation with λ = 1.5418 Å). Raman spectra were done on NEMUS670 NEXUS670FT-IR and nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were made on Micromeritics ASAP-2020HD88. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851) was applied to define the sulfur loading content at a ramping rate of 10°C min−1 under argon atmosphere. 2.4 Preparation of pure sulfur cathode and electrochemical measurements Sublimed sulfur and acetylene black (S/C) were mixed with a mass ratio of 3:1 and ball-milled for 60 min at 300 rmp. The obtained mixture was encapsulated in a sealed glass filled with argon and then heated at 155°C for 12 h. The cathode mixture contained 70 wt% S/C, 20 wt% acetylene black and 10 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, Kureha). In order to get the uniform slurry, the mixture was continuously stirred with N-methyl-2-pyrolidone (NMP) as dispersant for 30 min and casted on the aluminum foil (about 200 μm in thickness and 4.8 mg in weight), followed by drying for 12 h at 50°C in an electric oven. Then, it was cut into discs with a diameter of 12 mm and the sulfur mass was about 1–1.2 mg cm−2. The Li-S cells were assembled in CR2025-type coin cells and carried out in an argon-filled glove box. The interlayer was placed between the sulfur cathode and polypropylene separator (Celgard 2400), with the lithium foil as anode. The electrolyte was 1 M lithium bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonylimide with 2% LiNO3 as the additive in the mixture of 1,3-dioxolane and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (1/1, v/v). For comparison, the original cells without interlayer were also assembled under the same condition. The assembled cells were allowed to rest for 6 h before collecting electrochemical data. The galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles and cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were tested on a LAND CT2001A battery system between 1.7–2.8 V vs Li+/Li and electrochemical station CHI760E (Shanghai Chenhua) with a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1, respectively. 2.5 Computational details The magnetite Fe3O4 bulk adopts an “inverse spinel” structure, in which the Fe2+ atoms occupy half of the octahedral sites and the Fe3+ atoms locate in both the octahedral and the tetrahedral sub-lattices. The experimentally determined lattice parameter of the bulk (a = 8.396 Å) [45] is also used in the simulations. Among the various surface orientations, we adopt the (111) plane in the simulation model, not only because it is one of the prominent planes revealed from previous calculations [46], but also, it is often exposed in natural and synthetic Fe3O4 crystals. Due to the sequential stacking of different types of atoms along the [111] direction, there are six unique atomic terminations on the (111) plane. The Fetet1 termination [47], which contains a low density (1/4 monolayer) of both the octahedrally and tetrahedrally coordinated Fe atoms, is selected in the model. Such termination is not only confirmed in first-principles calculations [47] but also observed in several experiments [48]. Here, a 1 × 1 supercell corresponds to a lattice of 11.873 Å along the directions parallel to the surface. Accordingly, a 5 × 5 supercell of graphene that has a comparable lattice of 12.300 Å is adopted in the simulations. Spin-polarized calculations are performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [49] within the framework of density functional theory (DFT). The projector augmented wave (PAW) method is employed [50], and the wave functions are expanded by plane-wave basis sets with an energy cutoff of 400 eV. The exchange-correlation interactions of electrons are described by the optB86b-vdW functional [51], which explicitly accounts for the van der Waals forces. The first Brillouin zone is sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-mesh [52]. The Fetet1 terminated Fe3O4 (111) surface is simulated using a slab model which contains 12 atomic layers as well as a 16 Å vacuum region. During the geometry optimizations, the bottom six atomic layers are frozen while all other atoms including the adsorbates are allowed to relax until the maximum force is below 0.03 Å/eV. The DFT+U approach, which adopts a simplified rotationally invariant formulation by Dudarev et al. [53], is employed to describe Fe3O4, with the value of U eff (U eff = U–J), i.e., the difference between the on-site Coulomb parameter U and the exchange parameter J, set to be 3.8 eV. The same procedure is also applied to the adsorption on graphene, except that the effect of spin polarization is found to be negligible and the DFT+U is not employed. In all calculations, dipole corrections on total energies are added along the perpendicular direction. 2.6 Preparation of cells for in situ UV–vis spectra The sulfur cathode was prepared based on the above method. Both lithium foil and negative case were created with a hole of half the size of the cathode were created and 100 µL electrolyte was added to the cell. The assembly of cells coincided with the configuration of the way mentioned above. The cells were discharged at a current rate of 0.5 C and meanwhile, the UV–vis spectra were in situ taken at different voltages on the UV–Vis Spectrometer (Lambda 750, Japan). 3 Results and discussion As presented in Fig. 1 (a) (see the Experimental Section for details of the synthesis), the filter paper was firstly pretreated by covering with GO sheets (step i), wherein the pores inherent in paper can be covered and the specific area can be increased. In such way, the adsorption of ironic citrate was strongly favored by the capillarity, followed by the immersion in the GO solution (step ii). After drying, the paper was drawn with a pencil to render the encapsulation of graphite on both sides and finally the as-obtained paper containing ironic citrate, GO and graphite was annealed at 800 °C for 2 h in argon atmosphere (step iii). Then, the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer was attained finally, featured with inherent PC scaffold hybridized with Fe3O4 NPs, rGO sheets and graphite outface. In order to clearly clarify our preparation process and demonstrate the potential of the interlayer, we recorded each step of the preparation in detail with A4-paper-size filter paper (see Video S1 in the Supporting Information, SI). Obviously, the large-size interlayer was successfully obtained. The present strategy manifests notable advantages compared with the previous routes. First, the product can be scaled up demonstrated by the Video S1. If the filter paper is sufficiently large and enough, then more products can be fabricated in each batch. More significantly, the obtained different batches of interlayer are comparable in electrochemical performance. Second, the synthetic strategy is environmentally benign because of only water as the solvent during the preparation of interlayer. The combined merits of easy operation, eco-friendliness and cheap raw materials benefit large-scale synthesis. Of course, the further work needs to be carefully studied in near future. Compared with the previous research on the carbon-based hybrid as a free-standing interlayer, the as-obtained one in our study (Fig. 1(b)) possesses distinctive advantages. (i) The available three dimensional (3D) hierarchical porous structure formed a layered carbon-based interlayer, benefitting the transport of electrons and diffusion of ions. (ii) Due to the additional introduction of rGO and Fe3O4 NPs, the hybrid interlayer can concurrently ensure the physical and chemical confinement of sulfur molecules and any formed LiPSs. (iii) Using the pencil-drawing method, it easily overlays a layer of graphite on the backbone surface, which further improves the conductivity of the interface of interlayer and can further make full use of polysulfides in charge-discharge process. More specifically, this porous interlayer composed of Fe3O4 NPs, rGO, graphite, and PC is an excellent adsorbent, and possesses good electronic conductivity and abundant electrocatalytic active sites, also confirmed by shifted redox voltage peaks and first-principles calculations. These findings demonstrate that such a thin multiple interlayer is multifunctional in improving the cycle performance and rate capability of LSBs. The morphology and structure of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements. In Fig. S1(a), we can see that the surface of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer is covered with a layer of loose graphitic sheets. The detailed microstructure of graphitic sheets can be seen in Fig. S2, displaying the characteristic layer feature of graphite. Moreover, the interweaving long-fiber architecture inherent from the paternal paper can be also observable to form the porous network (Fig. S1(b)). From the cross-sectional FESEM image (Fig. S3), the thickness of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer is approximately 37 μm and the cross-linked porous network structure is clearly observed, which can generate more the electrochemical active sites for Li2S x deposition. The magnified FESEM images in Fig. 2 (a and b) further describe the remarkable wrinkles of the fibers. Numerous Fe3O4 NPs with the size range of 20–75 nm are encapsulated with rGO sheets, clearly demonstrated by Fig. 2(b and c). The TEM results in Fig. 2(d and e) are consistent with the above FESEM observations. The well-defined lattice fringes in Fig. 2(f) verify the high crystallization of Fe3O4 NPs. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) technique was applied to further characterize the interlayer. Fig. 2(g) obviously manifests that Fe3O4 NPs are uniformly distributed on the graphene sheet, agreeable with the FESEM/TEM observations. Fig. 2(h and j) indicates two representative HAADF-STEM images of the NPs, which provides the best evidence for the excellent crystallization of Fe3O4 NPs. As shown in Fig. 2(i and k), two atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM images are taken from the area marked with the green box in Fig. 2(h and j), respectively. Fig. 2(i) displays a typical Fe3O4 NP with remarkable lattice spacings of 0.48 and 0.30 nm corresponding to the (-1-11) and (-20-2) crystal planes of face-centered cubic (fcc) Fe3O4, respectively. While Fig. 2(j) describes the crystal lattice of (-1-1-1) and (-200) with different orientation from the above NP. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX; Fig. S4) analysis confirmed the formation of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite hybrid with carbon, iron and oxygen as the principal elemental components. STEM and the corresponding EDX elemental mappings indicated even spatial distribution of iron and oxygen throughout the nanocrystals anchored on the graphene sheets (Fig. 2(l)). Interestingly, through facilely tuning the number of process cycle, the Fe3O4 NPs can be readily engineered in terms of loading content and size. From FESEM images (Fig. S5(b and c)), it's found that discrete NPs are anchored onto the surface of GO nanosheets in case of one process cycle, indicating the lower loading than that of 3 process cycles (Fig. 2). Moreover, the particles are in a broad size distribution range from 13 to 50 nm (Fig. S5(d)). When the cycle number increases to 5, the sheets are distinctly observed to be thickly covered by the Fe3O4 NPs (Fig. S6(b–d)), which also grow bigger in the range of 30–87 nm. Observations tell us that the majority of NPs by 1 process cycle are below 20 nm, while other two samples obtained by 3 and 5 process cycles are dominated by bigger NPs with the size of larger than 70 and 80 nm. It should note here that the top surface looks almost unchanged by comparing the three samples (Figs. S1(a), S5(a) and S6(a)). In order to define the crystal structure of samples, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out to get the phase information of PC and PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite. As shown in Fig. S7(a), the PC shows two broad XRD peaks typical of the amorphous carbon. In contrast, PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite exhibits the sharp diffraction peaks and can be indexed as the fcc-Fe3O4 (JCPDS No. 19-0629) and graphite (JCPDS No. 26-1076), demonstrating the formation of the two phases. The Raman spectra of these samples are applied to detect the carbon structure. In Fig. S7(b), two similar characteristic peaks are observed at 1339 and 1587 cm−1 for PC and PC‖Fe3O4@rGO, i.e. D and G bands. The G band reflects the crystal disorder of carbon and the D band results from the ideal graphitic sp 2 lattice [25]. On the other hand, the Raman spectrum of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite also displayed the prominent D and G bands. But the much sharper and stronger G band marks a much lower I D/I G value than PC and PC‖Fe3O4@rGO. The comparative results strongly verify the presence of graphite on the surface of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer. The porous texture of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite is profiled by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms in Fig. S7(c). The notable absorption happens at the lower relative pressure range, a token of micropores. Another phenomenon of hysteresis appears, caused by the presence of mesopores. The corresponding pore size distribution in Fig. S7(d) agrees with the above analysis. The pore size ranges from micropores to macropores, mainly concentrating on the micro- and mesopores. Such hierarchical micro/meso/macroporous texture can strongly adsorb polysulfides and reduce the loss of active materials in the electrolyte. The network configuration of PC and multilevel pore structure formed by Fe3O4@rGO adsorbed on the fibers are beneficial to the volume expansion of sulfur and the rapid diffusion of ions. At the same time, the crosslinking structure also promotes the rapid transmission of electrons. On the contrary, the BET surface area of the PC is 287 m2 g−1 and only micropores exist (Fig. S8), which is harmful to the fast transfer of charge carriers and withstand the impact of high current. We first applied cyclic voltammetry (CV) to examine the discharge/charge reaction kinetics. The CV measurements were carried out in the coin cell with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer (Fig. 3 (a); 73% S, thermogravimetric analysis curve in Fig. S9), PC interlayer (Fig. S10) and without interlayer (Fig. 3(b)) for the initial 5 cycles between 1.7–2.8 V vs. Li+/Li at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. As indicated in Fig. 3(a), there are two pairs of obvious redox peaks, in which the cathodic peak (2.40–2.25 V) and the corresponding anodic peak (2.38–2.50 V) pertain to the transition from cyclo-sulfur (S8) to long-chain LiPSs, while the reduction peak (2.08–1.91 V) and the corresponding oxidation peak (2.25–2.38 V) belong to the long-chain LiPSs further reduction to Li2S2/Li2S, respectively [54,55]. A similar CV investigations on the electrode with PC interlayer (Fig. S10) and without interlayer (Fig. 3(b)) both show that the redox peaks are deformed and broadened (marked by rectangles), which reveals a slow kinetic process. Furthermore, the more highly coherent overlapping of the cathodic and anodic peaks in case of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite (marked by rectangles) demonstrates the better stability and reversibility of electrochemical process. Comparing the peak potentials (Fig. 3(c)) during the redox reactions, it is obvious that the electrode with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer indicates higher reduction peak voltage and lower oxidation peak potential than the pristine electrode without interlayer. This is a token of significant decrease of the electrode polarization, attributable to the catalysis role of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite on the redox reactions of S/Li2S [56,57]. These analytical results demonstrate that the introduction of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer can promote the redox kinetics and thus buffer the polarization for the LSBs. As expected, the cell with the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer indicate a high specific capacity of 1310 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.2 C (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1) and an excellent rate performance at even higher current densities (Fig. 3(d)). At current densities of 0.5, 1, 2, 4, and 6 C, the reversible capacities of LSBs with the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer are around 1034, 952, 871, 757 and 577 mAh g−1, respectively. Even at a relatively high rate of 10 C, the cell can still deliver a capacity as high as 478 mAh g−1. More significantly, when the current density is abruptly decreased to 0.5 C, the capacity is almost unchanged compared with its initial value at 0.5 C even undergoing 10 cycles at high rate of 10 C. Moreover, the two plateaus in the discharged curve were still evident even up to 10 C (Fig. S11). However, the counterparts with PC and without interlayer exhibit serious potential hysteresis even at a rate as low as 0.5 C in Fig. S11(b and c) and rise from slower redox kinetics [58]. The result indicates that the cells with the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer exhibit excellent rate capability and good reversibility during charge-discharge process. In contrast, the discharge capacities of cells with PC interlayer and without interlayer fade drastically and can't be comparable to those with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer. Especially at high rates, the capacity deteriorates fast and even to only 60 mAh g−1, i.e. one eighth of that of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer case. The result emphasized the high rate performance of cells with the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer due to the high conductivity endowed by the surface graphite and 3D network of PC substrate and the strong electrocatalytic effect on sulfur reduction given by Fe3O4 NPs. In general, the lower electronic conductivity of cathode sulfur and the higher solubility of formed LiPSs are related to the lower utilization of sulfur and the worse cycling stability of LSBs. LiPSs unavoidably dissolve into the electrolyte and diffuse to the anode side during the initial charge/discharge process due to the weak binding force between pristine separator and sulfur, leading to the weak cycling performance. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the cell with pristine separator delivers an initial discharge capacity of 893 mAh g−1, and drastically falls to 453 mAh g−1 after only 300 cycles at 0.5 C with a decay rate of 0.16% per cycle, showing obvious LiPSs shuttle. On the other hand, the conductive PC interlayer on the separator restricts the LiPSs within the cathode side, forming a catholyte chamber. Therefore, the cell with PC interlayer has a higher discharge capacity of 625 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles and maintains a discharge capacity of 344 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 3(e)). Further improvement was achieved by using PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer with an initial discharge capacity of 1242 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C and a high discharge capacity of 495 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C with an average capacity fading of only 0.06% per cycle (Fig. 3(e)). Additionally, the high Coulombic efficiency (CE>99.5%) for the cell with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer during the whole 1000 cycles confirms efficient blocking of soluble LiPSs’ shuttle (Fig. S12). Herein, in order to investigate the effect of contents and particle sizes of Fe3O4 on the performance, we measured the cycling stability of the sulfur cells with the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer at 0.5 C when the adsorption time of ferric citrate was 1 and 3, respectively. As shown in Fig. S13, the cell with three times adsorbed interlayer shows the higher reversible capacity and the better long cycling stability (also see Fig. 3(e)). The cell with the interlayer obtained via one time adsorption (1-time interlayer) delivers an initial discharge capacity of 1117 mAh g−1 and maintains a discharge capacity of only 585 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. Further improvement was achieved by using the 3-time interlayer with an initial discharge capacity of 1242 mAh g−1 and a high remaining discharge capacity of 660 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. The low content of polar Fe3O4 NPs on the interlayer cannot effectively confine the LiPSs within the cathode side during the repeated charge-discharge process. Therefore, properly increasing the content and size of Fe3O4 NPs is beneficial to the improvement of electrochemical performance. The Fe3O4 NPs have a strong electrocatalytic effect and chemical bonding with LiPSs, which not only has the ability to reduce loss of LiPSs but also to enhance the rate capability and cycling performance. For instance, the charge transfer resistance (R ct) is obviously decreased (Fig. S14). The lower resistance results from the conductive multifunctional interlayer, providing additional electron pathways to reach the S-containing species, enhancing the active material utilization. Even at 1 C, the cell with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer showed a discharge capacity of 1260 mAh g−1 in the 1st cycle, and a high discharge capacity of 661 mAh g−1 over prolonged 500 cycles with an average capacity fading of 0.09% per cycle, as well as a high CE of approximately 99% (Fig. 3(f)). In contrast, the cells with PC interlayer and without interlayer both showed faster capacity decay under identical testing conditions. The discharge capacity of the cell with PC interlayer dropped to 480 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles with a capacity decay rate of 0.11% per cycle (Fig. 3(f)). Particularly, the discharge capacity of the cell without interlayer rapidly dropped to approximately 480 mAh g−1 after only 300 cycles with a capacity decay rate of 0.17% per cycle, which is only 50.1% of the initial capacity (Fig. 3(f)). To demonstrate the ability of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer to capture LiPSs, we disassembled the coin cell after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C and performed FESEM and scanning TEM (STEM) and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) elemental mappings investigations. It can be found that the shape and structural integrity of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer kept the good structural integrity and the coexistence of sulfur and iron was clearly observed (Fig. S15), which confirms that the multifunctional interlayer possesses the excellent stability in cell cycling and the sulfur species can be effectively adsorbed. To further confirm the superiority of this interlayer in enhancing the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes, the cycling performance has been further tested at higher rates of 2, 4, and 10 C (Fig. S16). In Fig. S16(a), the cells are activated at 1C for 5 cycles firstly, followed by testing at 2 C and 4 C, respectively. After 500 cycles, the discharge capacities are retained at 660 and 590 mAh g−1 at 2 C and 4 C, respectively, and the corresponding capacity retentions are 56%, and 49% based on the initial discharge capacity, respectively. The CE approaches 100% at 4 C during the entire testing process. The predominance of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer is further verified by cycling at 10 C. As shown in Fig. S16(b), after activation stepwise with 1 C for 5 cycles and 5 C for 10 cycles, the cell continues to be operated at 10 C. An initial discharge capacity of 465.3 mAh g−1 is enabled at 10 C and the reversible capacity of 418 mAh g−1 is maintained after 500 cycles, during which the decay is only 0.02% per cycle based on the initial capacity at 10 C. To our knowledge, such long cycling at a high rate of 10 C has rarely been reported and a comparative result is present in Table S1 to compare with other related interlayer. The above results testify that the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer promotes the high rate capability and long cycling with high power output. In consideration of the needs of practical applications, it is crucial to provide a high areal sulfur loading to obtain a high energy density. Sulfur cathodes with a series of sulfur loadings were tested (Fig. 4 ). In case of 2.45 and 3.61 mg cm−2 (Fig. 4(a)), the discharge capacities of 1003 mAh g−1 (2.46 mAh cm−2), and 696 mAh g−1 (2.51 mAh cm−2) are maintained for the cells at 0.2 C after 200 cycles, respectively, accounting for 76.7%, and 78% of their initial capacities. Additionally, it should be mentioned that the recent literature reveals the more emphasis on the electrolyte amount [59,60]. The addition of interlayer will inevitably increase the value of E/S, which is a challenging problem faced by the researchers to do the separator modification and the interlayer. However, with increase of the areal sulfur mass loadings, the value of E/S will become smaller. Herein, in order to investigate the sulfur utilization efficiency of higher-sulfur-loading electrodes and maximize the actual energy density, we further tested the performance of LSBs with higher areal sulfur mass loadings. Notably, when the sulfur mass loadings has been increased to 5.85 mg cm−2, a high capacity of 681 mAh g−1 (3.90 mAh cm−2) at 0.2 C can be delivered in the 100th cycle (Fig. 4(b)), corresponding to 89.5% of the fifth cycle discharge capacity. With further increase to 8.05 mg cm−2, the capacity can still be as high as 518 mAh g−1 (4.17 mAh cm−2) at 0.1 C after 100 cycles (Fig. 4(b)), corresponding to 76.3% of the fifth cycle discharge capacity, and shows good capacity retention. when the sulfur mass loadings is 8.05 mg cm−2, the value of E/S is about 8, which is comparable to the previous reports (Table S2). The performance of LSBs with high areal sulfur loading is fundamental and great challenging for proceeding on the way to the practical application. The prolonged cycling life of the pristine S cathode with the sulfur loading of 2.11 mg cm−2 is further measured at 0.5 C (Fig. 4(c)). It delivers an initial discharge capacity of 1002 mAh g−1. Then, the cell retains a very stable cycle life, and obtains a capacity of 570 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles, corresponding to a small capacity decay ratio of 0.1% per cycle. In consideration of the relatively high areal sulfur loading, the pristine sulfur cathode is believed to display the good cycling performance. The polysulfide permeation measurement also indicates no color changed in the side of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer after even 36 h (Fig. S17). These results indicate that the cells with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer indicate excellent cycling performance and high reversible capacity even with high sulfur loading, further manifesting that the multifunctional interlayer not only effectively confines the soluble LiPSs within the cathode side, but also improves the conductivity of the cells. In-situ UV–vis spectroscopy is applied to effectively and qualitatively detect the discharge products during discharging in accord with the Beer–Lambert's law, due to the characteristic colors of the polysulfide species [61]. Fig. 5 (a) shows the scheme of the cell assembly configuration sealed with a glass window for the detection of polysulfides formed on the separator. The layout could enable the simultaneity of UV–vis measurement and the battery testing, exclusive of the need to take the electrolyte out. To qualitatively and qualitatively gain the information from the spectra obtained, several standard catholytes at 20 × 10−3 M were tested as shown in Fig. 5(b). These catholytes were prepared directly by the reaction between stoichiometric amounts of Li2S and sulfur in 1 M lithium bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) with a mixture of 1,3-sdioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (1/1 v/v) as the solvent. As expected, the dissolved LiPSs exhibited reflectance toward the long wavelengths in the UV–vis spectrum consistent with the colors of the LiPSs. Specifically, the position of the absorption edge in the UV–vis spectra shifted toward long wavelengths as the ratio between sulfur and lithium became higher. In order to find a way to discern the different LiPSs, we concentrated on the peak position of the first derivative spectra of the original data. As presented in Fig. 5(c), such a platform gave us the clear determination of the featured wavelength of various LiPSs, applied to define the LiPSs during the cell cycling [62]. The main peak positions of Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4 and Li2S2 were observable at 570, 535, 510 and 450 nm, respectively. To definitely discriminate the species of LiPSs in real time during the discharge process, the LiPSs relevant to the discharge depths were qualitatively analyzed and profiled by different colors in Fig. S18. At the high voltage plateau, a notable phenomenon existed that the reflectance intensity declined as the wavelength red-shifted in the UV–vis spectra, pertaining to the evolution of long-chain LiPSs (marked by cyan curve). As the discharging proceeded, the mid-chain LiPSs (blue curve) and short-chain LiPSs (red curve) were detectable with the absorbance from long to short wavelengths. Fig. 5(d–f) indicates the reflectance spectra collected from sulfur cells with PC, PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite and without interlayer when discharging at a rate of 0.5 C from 2.7 to 1.7 V vs. Li+/Li. The notable difference among the three cells can be distinctly observable. The reflectance of the cell without interlayer clearly shows a fast decrease in the long-wavelength spectrum and an increase in the low-mid wavelength range, while the other two cells indicate similar profile. At the beginning stage of the discharging, the reflectance results from the absorption of the separator humidified by the electrolyte. Upon the discharge proceeding, the reflectance intensity shows no change from the beginning in Fig. 5(e and f) especially in the long-wavelength area. The further and direct comparison can be derived from the corresponding first-order derivatives of the above UV–vis reflection spectra (Fig. 5(g–i)). As for the three cells, a consecutive variation of the derivative peaks is found from long to short wavelengths. Notably, as discharge proceeds in the cell without interlayer, the intensity of the peaks assigned to Li2S2 and Li2S4 becomes stronger, while the peaks for Li2S6 and Li2S8 increase first and then decrease (Fig. 5(g)). The result vividly shows us the stepwise transformation of sulfur into LiPSs to finally Li2S2 or Li2S. In contrast, the derivative peaks for Li2S4, Li2S6 and Li2S8 almost can't be observed for the cells, especially with PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite (Fig. 5(h and i)), revealing that the LiPSs can't go through the separator to the lithium anode due to the powerful obstruction of the interlayer. These results provide a direct evidence for the superior performance of the PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer to effectively alleviate the shuttling of LiPSs. Theoretical simulations are also further performed to reveal the underlying reasons for the excellent performance of the cell with (PC)‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer. We find that the interactions between LiPSs and Fe3O4 are sufficiently strong to inhibit the “shuttling” of LiPSs toward the lithium metal anode. In Fig. 6 (a–f), one can see that via the formation of the covalent bonds, the S atoms in LiPSs can effectively bind to the widespread Fe atoms located at the outermost layer of Fe3O4. In addition, significant charge transfer occurs from Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8) to Fe3O4, with the corresponding amounts being 1.02, 1.17, 0.82, 0.83, and 0.43 e− , respectively, for the adsorption of Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 according to the Bader charge analysis. Moreover, the ubiquitous van der Waals force also contributes to the interactions between LiPSs and the Fe3O4 substrates. Thereby, the large adsorption energies of LiPSs on Fe3O4 (Fig. 6(g)) originate from the co-action of covalent bonds, charge transfer, and van der Waals interactions. In the absence of Fe3O4, by contrast, the situation becomes quite different. In this case, strong covalent bonds can hardly form between the S atoms and the rGO substrate. When n is larger than 2, the charge transfer between Li2S n and the substrate is negligible, being less than 0.03 e− . This makes van der Waals force the main source of interactions between the two parts, which, consequently, brings about the much-reduced adsorption energies (Figs. 6(g) and S19). Our simulations also indicate that the presence of Fe3O4 could improve the kinetics of the charging and discharging processes. Unlike the Li2S n adsorption on other metal oxides like TiO2 [63] and MnO2 [64] where Li cations are localized between S atoms and the oxides, on Fe3O4 the Li cations are no longer bound by S atoms and can be well separated on the Fe3O4 substrate, locating on the hollow sites formed by three O atoms (Fig. 6(a–e)). Thus, the adsorption and desorption of the Li species could become more easily on Fe3O4 than those on TiO2 and MnO2, resulting in facile charging and discharging processes. Besides, the deposition of the Li species may also trigger the cleavage of the S-S bonds. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the appearance of the two Li cations help to convert S8 to two S4 units, which may promote the further deposition of Li species in the discharging process. In our work, the free-standing PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite interlayer is featured with the integration of advantageous configurations. Paper-derived carbon matrix provides the porous scaffold and myriad active sites, favorable for the intimate contact with electrolyte and the fast transport of Li ion and electrons. Moreover, Fe3O4 NPs embedded in the graphene layers possess high surface area and can also increase the physical and chemical adsorption of LiPSs intermediates to minimize the dissolution into the electrolyte. The outer graphite layer on both sides with notable electronic conductivity can favor the electron collection and thus enhance the reutilization of S-containing species to enhance the reaction kinetics [65]. The interlayer should allow for the ready storage of electrons and LiPSs, i.e. the second current collector and reservoir of sulfur species [66]. The LiPSs dissolved can be sequestered for electrochemical reactions so that the sulfur can rapidly redistribute throughout the interlayer. Such configuration promotes the reutilization of sulfur, provides more space for sulfur location and refrains the LiPSs from shuttling to the anode. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have devised and produced a free-standing multifunctional and hierarchical porous PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite hybrid interlayer, which is synthesized via a capillary and pencil-drawing method using filter paper as backbone. The hybrid interlayer possesses the merits of high specific surface area, 3D interwoven fiber network, hierarchically porous structure, enhanced polarity, superior conductivity, and strong catalytic effect. It can efficiently preserve the lithium polysulfides, channel the electrolyte, and promote a fast transport of the Li ions and electrons. The inhibition of lithium polysulfides shuttling has been verified through in situ UV-vis absorption spectra, kinetics analysis, and first-principles simulations. The use of PC‖Fe3O4@rGO‖graphite in lithium-sulfur batteries makes simple sulfur cathodes be able to display excellent performance such as greatly enhanced capacity, long cycling stability, and ultrahigh rate capability. The batteries deliver discharge capacities of 495 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C for 1000 cycles, and 661, 660, 590, and 418 mAh g−1 at 1, 2, 4, and even 10 C for 500 cycles, respectively. Even when the sulfur loading is as high as 8.05 mg cm−2, a reversible capacity of 518 mAh g−1 (4.17 mAh cm−2) can be achieved at 0.1 C with more than 98% CE after 100 cycles. The strategy proposed in this work will help the rational design of novel interlayer materials with multi-functionalities and can have important consequences in applications of advanced lithium–sulfur batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) are regarded as a competitive next-generation energy storage device. However, their practical performance is seriously restricted due to the undesired polysulfides shuttling. Herein, a multifunctional interlayer composed of paper-derived carbon (PC) scaffold, Fe3O4 nanoparticles, graphene, and graphite sheets is designed for applications in LSBs. The porous PC skeleton formed by the interweaving long-fibers not only facilitates fast transfer of Li ions and electrons but also provides a physical barrier for the polysulfide shuttling. The secondary Fe3O4@graphene component can reduce the polarization, boost the attachment of polysulfides, and promote the charging-discharging kinetics. The outer graphitic sheets layers benefit the interfacial electrochemistry and the utilization of S-containing species. The efficient obstruction of polysulfides diffusion is further witnessed via in situ ultraviolet-visible characterization and first-principles simulations. When 73% sulfur/commercial acetylene black is used as the cathode, the cell exhibits excellent capacity retention with high capacities at 0.5 C for 1000 cycles and even up to 10 C for 500 cycles, an ultrahigh rate capability up to 10 C (478 mAh g−1), and a high areal-sulfur loading of 8.05 mg cm−2. The strategy paves the way for developing multifunctional composites for LSBs with superior performance.
